header.name: chaos/preprocessor/algorithm/fold_left.h
header.author: Paul Mensonides
header.overview: The header defines an algorithm that accumulates the elements of a from the first element to the last element.

macro.abstract: The macro accumulates the elements of its second argument with the operation specified by its first argument.

param.para:
The operation that is to be used to accumulate the elements of g. This operation must be either a or a macro name that refers to a macro with a signature compatible with the following pseudo-signature:
op(s, elem†, state‡)
† If the type of g is non-variadic, elem must be the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of sub-elements in each element of g. Otherwise, elem must be a single parameter.
‡ The state pseudo-parameter must be either ... or the number of parameters that corresponds to the number of arguments in the accumulation state, __VA_ARGS__.

macro.para:
The macro itself expands to a in terms of (s). This , when invoked by , expands to the result of accumulating the elements of g, from left to right, with the user-specified operation. This is illustated by the following pseudo-code:
op(s, g[length(g) - 1], ... op(s, g[1], op(s, g[0], state)) ... )

An invocation of the operation with the current (s), a particular element (elem), and current state (state or __VA_ARGS__) expands to a new state used in the accumulation of subsequent elements (or as the final result of the algorithm if no further elements exist). The operation may also expand to a in terms of (s) that expands to a new state. Expansion to a allows the operation to recurse on itself if necessary.
Invocations of the operation are trampolined such that each invocation is invoked with ((s)), where s is the original at the beginning of the algorithm (i.e. ()). This maximizes the utility of the .

Ignoring the complexity of op (which is invoked once for each element in g), the efficiency of the algorithm's use of the can be described in terms of the number of required to complete the algorithm. The asymptotic upper and lower bounds are Θ(2n+2), where n is the number of elements in g.
This macro deduces the current and invokes . If the current is already known, direct use of is more efficient.
